newsitem.title: JAPAN: Despite Hamanaka plea, court goes on.
newsitem.headline: Despite Hamanaka plea, court goes on.

text.p: Despite pleading guilty to fraud and conspiracy charges on Monday, one-time Sumitomo Corp copper trading king Yasuo Hamanaka must still face trial.
Japan's legal system calls for a lengthy examination of evidence even if the defendant pleads guilty to ensure the prosecution's case is backed up by factual evidence.
The court set sessions for March 10 and March 17, when the defence will question a company official about how Sumitomo supervised its dealers.
The witness is Yoshio Takeuchi from Sumitomo's Non-ferrous Metals/Chemicals/Petroleum and Carbon Group's Credit and Controlling Department.
"It (the testimony) will allow us to hear directly what the system of checks at Sumitomo headquarters was like," Hamanaka's lawyer Hidessato Sekine told reporters.
The two charges carry a penalty of up to 15 years in prison. Defence lawyers hope to present evidence that show mitigating factors to try to reduce the sentence.
There is no jury system in Japan, with the three-judge panel making the decision on the sentence.
Hamanaka, 49, who spent all of his professional life at Sumitomo, was fired last June for what the company said was a decade of unauthorised trading that cost it $2.6 billion.
